title: Enabling TLS for privacy results in exception

labels.name: TeamGroot
labels.description: GH issues worked on by Groot Team

body:
### Steps to Reproduce (Bug)
1. Generate a client certificate and key for Besu
2. Generate PKCS12 keystore and set password
3. Add keystore password to a file
4. Configure the keystore using the --privacy-tls-keystore-file option.
5. Configure the file that contains the password to decrypt the keystore using the --privacy-tls-keystore-password-file option.
6. Configure a fingerprint file - containing fingerprinbt from Orion node configured for client connection TLS --privacy-tls-known-enclave-file
7. Enable TLS for privacy --privacy-tls-enabled=true
8. Start besu

**Expected behavior:** 
Server should start and should be able to 'communicate' over TLS to Orion.

**Actual behavior:** 
Server fails to start with following exception

**Frequency:** 
Every time

### Versions
* Software version: besu/v1.4.1/linux-x86_64/oracle_openjdk-java-11
* Java version: openjdk 11.0.4 2019-07-16 LTS
* OS Name & Version: CentOS Linux release 7.7.1908 (Core)

### Additional Information

Looks like bug in EnclaveFactory.java in package org.hyperledger.besu.enclave 

The function readSecretFromFile is reading the password file as bytes not a line... so you get EOL characters 

Simple fix:
return Files.readAllLines(path, Charsets.UTF_8).get(0);

Thanks for raising this, we'll look into fixing this for the next minor release. In the meantime, you can use this workaround to set the password:

`echo -n "Type your password:";read -s password;echo -ne $password > passwordFile;`
